questions.text: Koebner's phenomenon is seen in all except
questions.solution:
Koebner phenomenon is a dermatological condition characterized by the appearance of new skin lesions at sites of injury, such as cuts, scrapes, or burns. These lesions often resemble the original skin condition.

Key characteristics of Koebner phenomenon:

  • New lesions appear at sites of injury: This is the defining feature of Koebner phenomenon.
  • Lesions resemble the original skin condition: The new lesions often have the same appearance, texture, and characteristics as the existing skin condition.
  • Can occur with various skin conditions: Koebner phenomenon can be associated with a wide range of skin disorders, including psoriasis, lichen planus, vitiligo, and atopic dermatitis.

Option D : Herpes Infection Doesn't show kobener phenomenon.

Key Takeaway :

The Koebner phenomenon is a dermatological condition characterized by the appearance of new skin lesions at sites of injury seen in psoriasis, lichen planus and vitiligo.

questions.text: What skin condition is characterized by the presence of coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp?
questions.solution:
• Etiological agent: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Lesions of erythrasma are asymptomatic, erythematous to hyperpigmented. Occurs in the axilla, groin, or inframammary area.
  • Colors on wood's lamp:
    • Erythrasma- Coral red
    • Versicolor- Yellow
    • Tinea capitis (Microsporum sp.)- Blue-Green
    • Tinea capitis (T. schoenleinii)- Dull blue
    • Vitiligo- Chalky white

Options B, C and D : They do not show fluorescence on wood's lamp examination.

Key Takeaway :

Erythrasma is characterized by coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp, caused by the bacterium Corynebacterium minutissimum. It typically presents as asymptomatic, erythematous to hyperpigmented lesions in areas like the axilla, groin, or inframammary folds

questions.text: Identify labeled structure-
questions.solution:
• Cutaneous membranes
    1. Epidermis

  • Accessory structures
    1. Hair

  • Sweat Glands

  • Sebaceous Glands
    1. Apocrine gland: These are sweat glands that are typically found in the axillary and genital regions and secrete a thicker fluid into the hair follicles.
    2. Eccrine gland: These sweat glands are found throughout the skin and are responsible for thermoregulation through sweat production.
    3. Sebaceous gland: These glands produce sebum, an oily substance that lubricates the skin and hair.
    4. Arrector pili muscle: This small muscle is attached to hair follicles and is responsible for causing hair to stand on end (goosebumps).
  • The pilosebaceous unit is composed of a hair follicle, arrector pili muscle, and sebaceous gland.

Key takeaway :

The pilosebaceous unit is composed of a hair follicle, arrector pili muscle, and sebaceous gland. Apocrine eccrine and sebaceous gland are attached to it.

questions.text: A 34 year old male presented with skin lesion over lower back, scalp. On eliciting a clinical test, there was pinpoint bleeding. This sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
When scales of psoriasis are scraped, characteristic coherence of a silvery scale like a candle wax is seen (Grattage test).

The Auspitz sign is a clinical feature observed in certain skin conditions. It refers to the appearance of small bleeding points when the top layer of a lesion is gently scraped off. This sign is most commonly seen in psoriasis vulgaris, but it can also be present in other conditions such as Darier disease and actinic keratosis.

Conditions where Auspitz sign is not typically seen:

  • Inverse psoriasis: This type of psoriasis affects skin folds and is not usually associated with the Auspitz sign.
  • Pustular psoriasis: This condition involves the formation of pus-filled blisters and does not typically exhibit the Auspitz sign.
  • Guttate psoriasis: This type of psoriasis is characterized by small, drop-like lesions and does not usually show the Auspitz sign.
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis: This severe form of psoriasis involves widespread redness and scaling of the skin and is not typically associated with the Auspitz sign.

Auspitz sign seen in- Psoriasis vulgaris, Darier disease, Actinic keratosis

Not seen in - Inverse psoriasis, pustular psoriasis, guttate psoriasis, erythrodermic psoriasis (Option C)

Option A- Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

Option C - Auspitz sign seen in- Psoriasis vulgaris, Darier disease, Actinic keratosis. Not seen in - Inverse psoriasis, pustular psoriasis, guttate psoriasis, erythrodermic psoriasis

Option D- Tin tack sign is seen in DLE (Discoid lupus erythematosus).

Key takeaway:

When scales are completely scraped off, basement membrane is exposed as seen as moist red surface( membrane of Bulkeley) through which dilated capillaries at the top of elongated dermal papillae are torn, leading to multiple bleeding points.This sign is known as Auspitz sign.

questions.text: Tzanck smear is used for diagnosis for all except-
questions.solution:
Tzank smear is a useful investigation in patients with fluid filled lesions to differentiate pemphigus vulgaris and herpes infection.

  • HSV-I, HSV-II and VZV are herpes viruses show multinucleated giant cells on tzanck smear.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris shows Acantholytic cells in Tzanck smear.
  • Molluscum contagiosum shows Handerson Patterson bodies in Tzanck smear.

Option C : Tzank smear is not useful for detecting HIV.

Options A , B & D : HSV-I, HSV-II and VZV are herpes viruses, which show multinucleated giant cells on tzanck smear.

Key takeaway:

  • HSV-I, HSV-II and VZV are herpes viruses, which show multinucleated giant cells on tzanck smear.

questions.text: A 40 year old female leprosy patient started MB pack recently presented with increased inflammation of preexisting lesions as shown in the image. On examination, there was lagophthalmos. What is incorrect regarding this case?
questions.solution:
This is a case of type 1 lepra reaction.

TYpe 1 reactions are delayed hypersensitivity reactions, characterized by increased inflammation of pre existing lesions. It is associated with neuritis (acute loss of function). ( Option D )

Risk factors:

  • Borderline spectrum of leprosy (BT,BB,BL). ( Option A )
  • Starting of treatment
  • Female gender due to hormonal influence, Pregnancy. ( Option B )
  • Previous episodes of reaction

Management of type 1 reaction

  • Continue MDT
  • Mild reaction: NSAIDs
  • Severe reaction: Corticosteroid is DOC

Thalidomide is of no value in Type I reaction. It is used in management of type II reactions. ( Option C )

Key Takeaway:

Type 1 Lepra Reaction :

  • Type 4 HSn
  • MC In Borderline Groups , Female
  • Rx - Continue MDT with Steroids.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not show this type of giant cells?
questions.solution:
Langhans' giant cells have horseshoe-shaped nuclei arrangement at one pole of the cell. These are formed by fusion of epithelioid cells. They are not phagocytic but secrete interleukins and help in inflammation. These giant cells are seen in granulomatous conditions ( Option A, C D ) like-

  • Tubercular granuloma
  • Tuberculoid leprosy
  • Deep fungal infection
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leishmaniasis
  • Crohn's disease

Option B :

In lepromatous leprosy there is diffuse infiltration of macrophages, plasma cells. There is a clear grenz zone. Many foam cells with globi- cigar shaped bundles of M. leprae inside macrophage. These swollen macrophages packed with bacilli are known as lepra or virchow cells.

Key Takeaway:

Lepromatous Leprosy Histopath

  • Subepidermal Clear Grenz Zone
  • Lepra Cells Which are Foamy cells Containing AFB
  • No Giant Cells.

Option B. Clofazimine:

Clofazimine is an antileprosy drug that is known to cause pigmentation of the skin.

It can lead to a reddish-brown to black (mahogany red) discoloration of the skin, which is a well-recognized side effect of the medication.

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin can cause red-orange discoloration of bodily fluids (such as urine, sweat, and tears) but does not typically cause pigmentation of the skin itself.

Option C: Dapsone: Dapsone is another antileprosy drug, and while it can cause side effects such as hemolytic anemia and hypersensitivity reactions, it does not generally cause pigmentation.

Option D: Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used for various infections, including leprosy, but it is not associated with pigmentation changes in the skin.

Key takeaway:

Clofazimine causes mahogany red pigmentation

questions.text: A 35 year-old female patient presented with a hypopigmented patch over the left forearm measuring 5 centimeters for the past one month. HPE showed skin with the subepidermal region showing numerous epithelioid granulomas surrounded by lymphocytes. A diagnosis of Hansen's disease was made. The Earliest sensation to be lost in Hansen's disease is:
questions.solution:
First sensation to be lost in leprosy: Temp (cold > hot)

Patients cannot sense extremes of hot or cold. The next sensation lost is touch (light pressure), followed by pain and finally deep pressure.

MC cranial nerve involved: Facial

MC peripheral nerve involved: Ulnar > Posterior Tibial

Option A : Pain Sensation is lost after Temperature loss.

Option B : Touch Sensation is lost after Temperature.

Option C : Vibration is lost after Temperature.

Key Takeaway :

Order of Loss of Sensation in Leprosy :

  • Temperature ( Cold > Hot )
  • Touch ( Light Pressure )
  • Pain
  • Deep Pressure

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient has a known case of leprosy with multiple, bilaterally symmetrical Plaques and nodules over face, ears, trunk. Glove & stocking anesthesia is present. Which of the following is not treatment of lepra reaction seen in this given type of leprosy?
questions.solution:
Based on given clinical presentation, diagnosis is lepromatous leprosy with Type 2 Lepra reaction.

  • Cessation of anti leprosy treatment is not the treatment of type 2 lepra reaction. Antileprosy treatment should be continued.

Treatment of lepra type 2 reaction :

Mild/ moderate (fever with few skin lesions):

  • Rest
  • Chloroquine
  • Aspirin
  • Antimonials (when associated with bone and joint problem)

Severe ENL (neuritis/ arthritis/ uveitis/ orchitis):

  • Steroid
  • Clofazimine (in large doses)
  • Thalidomide

Option A : Clofazimine - For Severe ENL (neuritis/ arthritis/ uveitis/ orchitis)

Option B : Thalidomide - of no value in Type I reaction. It is used in management of type II reaction. It is teratogenic hence contraindicated in women.

Option C : Corticosteroids - For Severe ENL (neuritis/ arthritis/ uveitis/orchitis)

Key Takeaway:

Lepra Reactions Rx

  • Continue MDT
  • Steroids Mainstay
  • Thalidomide and Clofazamine in type 2.

questions.text: A 9 year old child presented with bluish red, subcutaneous swellings over the cervical region for several months. Some of the lesions underwent spontaneous healing leaving typical, cord-like scars. Infection of underlying cervical lymph nodes is present. Histology showed marked caseating necrosis. Given type of cutaneous tuberculosis is known as?
questions.solution:
Scrofuloderma

  • Multibacillary type of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • It develops as infection into the skin from an underlying focus, usually lymph nodes and occasionally bone, joint.
  • MC in children.
  • MC lymph node involved: Cervical lymph node
  • Begins as asymptomatic, bluish red, subcutaneous swellings that persist for several months and overlie an infected gland or joint.
  • Numerous fistulae may intercommunicate beneath ridges of a bluish skin and some may open draining sinuses onto the skin surface.
  • Spontaneous healing can occur, but the course is very protracted and leaves typical, cord-like scars.
  • Histology shows marked caseating necrosis, in which there are usually numerous bacteria.

Option B: Lupus Vulgaris

  • MC type of cutaneous TB
  •  Hematogenous spread (Endogenous> Exogenous)
  • Clinical features:
  • Erythematous/Violaceous [purplish] plaque with central scarring [Central clearing is seen in Tinea; Central crusting is seen in Leishmaniasis].
  • On diascopy (pressing of the lesion with glass slide) Golden brown, Apple jelly nodules are seen at the periphery of the lesion.

Option C: Erythema Nodosum

  • Causes: Idiopathic, Drugs, OCPs, Sarcoidosis, Streptococcal infections, Ulcerative colitis, Mycobacterial hypersensitivity, Maternal causes.
  • Presents as Erythematous nodules over anterior leg which ulcerate.

Option D: Ecthyma Gangrenosum

  • Ecthyma is a deeper variant of impetigo.
  • Indurated lesion with necrotic crust → on removal → forms ulcer.
  • Three types
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum: Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Ecthyma pyogenicum: Strep, Staph aureus
  • Ecthyma contagiosum/Contagious pustular disease/Orf disease- Parapoxvirus/ ORF virus. It is a zoonotic viral condition which spreads via sheep goat.

Key takeaway:

Scrofuloderma

  • It develops as infection into the skin from an underlying focus, usually lymph nodes and occasionally bone, joint.
  • MC affects cervical lymph nodes in children.
  • Begins as asymptomatic, bluish red, subcutaneous swellings that persist for several months and overlie an infected gland or joint.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is characteristic of lupus vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Lupus vulgaris:

  • MC type of cutaneous TB
  • Hematogenous spread (Endogenous> Exogenous)
  • Clinical features: Erythematous/Violaceous [purplish] plaque with central scarring [Central clearing is seen in Tinea; Central crusting is seen in Leishmaniasis].
  • On diascopy (pressing of the lesion with glass slide) Golden brown, Apple jelly nodules are seen at the periphery of the lesion.

Option A: Honey-colored crusts

This feature is typical of impetigo, not lupus vulgaris. Impetigo presents with crusted lesions due to bacterial infection.

Option B: Apple jelly nodules on diascopy

This is a classic sign of lupus vulgaris. When pressed with a glass slide, the nodules appear as golden-brown, translucent lesions, resembling apple jelly.

Option C: Vesicular lesions

Vesicular lesions are characteristic of conditions like herpes simplex or chickenpox, not lupus vulgaris.

Option D: Ulceration with necrotic tissue

lupus vulgaris typically presents with raised, well-defined plaques rather than necrotic ulcers.

Key Takeaway :

Lupus vulgaris:

  • MC type of cutaneous TB
  • Hematogenous spread (Endogenous> Exogenous)
  • Clinical features: Erythematous/Violaceous [purplish] plaque with central scarring [Central clearing is seen in Tinea; Central crusting is seen in Leishmaniasis].
  • On diascopy (pressing of the lesion with glass slide) Golden brown, Apple jelly nodules are seen at the periphery of the lesion.
